So oft as I the Splendour do behold</br>Of heav'nly Graces, linkt in golden chaine,</br>Which them so firmely doth together hold,</br>That all they but as one seeme to remaine;</br>My Soule is so delighted with their traine,</br>That she desires to dwell with them for ay;</br>But oft employment, pleasures, cares and gaine,</br>Mine eyes and heart so draw another way,</br>I fleshly motions more than spirituall obay.

And as these Graces joyn'd, my soule delight,</br>So doth each singled out by Meditation,</br>Sing I of Love, I love with all my might:</br>If Humblenesse, she workes humiliation:</br>So Faith, Repentance, Hope, Justification,</br>By Righteousnesse imputed:  Mercy kind,</br>Joy, Patience, Fortitude, chast Conversation,</br>Peace, Meeknesse, Prayer, Zeale, ev'n all I find</br>Do alwayes to my Song, both sute mine heart and mind.

But such are my Corruptions innate,</br>Hels malice, and the worlds enticements vaine,</br>I can no longer hold that happy state,</br>Than I in Contemplation remaine:</br>This is the cause my Muse is now so faine</br>To sing of Constancie, that heav'nly Grace,</br>Which all the rest doth ay with us retaine</br>Most glorious Grace!  the lustre of whose face,</br>Both heav'nly Love, and all her Peeres for ever grace.

For, without Her, the rest are all but showes,</br>Like Corne by high-wayes side, flourish awhile,</br>And seemes more glorious, than that which grows</br>Upon best bottom'd, dunged, tilled Soyle:</br>But as that onely doth our eyes beguile</br>With flourishes, in calme and gentle spring,</br>But Summers heate, and frosts, it's verdure spoile:</br>Ev'n so, these rootlesse Vertues flourishing,</br>Adverse or prosp'rous Fortune to confusion bring.

Thou, that art from Eternity the same,</br>Without least shadow of Variety:</br>Like to the Sun, heav'ns pure world-lightning flame,</br>Constant in beate, course, and serenitie:</br>Three, yet subsisting in one Deitie,</br>Who, though thou seem'st to change with things below,</br>Art farre in truth from Mutability:</br>Oh make mine heart in vertue constant grow,</br>That thence, as from a Fountaine, this Discourse may flow.

We Constancie a Perseverance call</br>In some good purpose:  for in ev'ry thing</br>We undertake, right must be first of all</br>Resolv'd of, next, our firme persevering:</br>A vaine, unsettled, idle wavering</br>Without just ground, by Proteus, Poets faine,</br>Who on himselfe as many formes will bring,</br>As he hath idle notions in his braine,</br>Or base desires and Lusts which in his heart remaine.

But in good purpose to stand fast and sound,</br>Not onely man-like is, but most divine,</br>Like God, in whom no change was ever found:</br>For as the Sunne, this worlds pure crystall eyne,</br>In heav'n doth alwaies with like glory shine,</br>Though, by the varying Medium's here below,</br>It seeme more glorious in the Summer time,</br>Than when Eolian blasts darke clouds do blow:</br>So Constance is the same, though alt'ring oft in show.

This Constance is with Patience a twin,</br>Begot by Jupiter of Fortitude;</br>Mother and Babes as like, as neere of kin;</br>Who hath one, with all three must be indude:</br>These lift up to heroicall habitude,</br>And come from Justice, and a prudent mind.</br>If Fury, Rage, Wrong, Rashnesse do intrude,</br>We them no vertues faire, but vices find,</br>With whom Minerva, nor the Graces ever joyn'd.

Patience and Constancie in this agree,</br>Effeminate faint hearts ay to oppose,</br>And men relieve in all extremitie,</br>Undanted, resolute, who will not loose</br>That liberty, they have the Good to choose:</br>Thus seeme they one:  now marke their difference,</br>Patience all wrongs with courage undergoes:</br>For without Suffering's no Patience:</br>But Constance is in joy and paine a firme defence.

Without Compulsion, free for Vertues sake,</br>Patience constrain'd, oft by necessity,</br>Most cheerefull valiantly doth undertake</br>To beare, what cannot well avoyded be:</br>One good end Constancie propounds, which she</br>Onely regards:  but noble patience,</br>Before her will all evils conquerd see,</br>Which her oppresse in flesh or conscience:</br>Both have brave resolution, and sound confidence.

No fury of the headlesse Multitude,</br>No Tyrants rage a constant mind can shake;</br>Though all the world turne to a Chaos rude,</br>The ruines crush him may, but can not make</br>Him stagger, nor Joves thunder make him quake.</br>The Sea may roare, the waves mount to the skies,</br>And threaten him to drowne in deepest Lake:</br>But Fury, Rage, Waves, all he doth despise,</br>And when hopes outward faile, his inward highest rise.

He constant perseveres unto the end,</br>Like some good traveller, who gives not in,</br>Till he attaine the place he doth intend:</br>And as the Souldier, that the towne would winne,</br>Fights stoutly, till he conquers all within:</br>Ev'n so in Buildings, Arts, or Merchandize,</br>In any Worke or Science we beginne,</br>It is the end where all our glory lyes;</br>He runs in vaine, that faints before he wins the Prize.

Though all her meanes, and all her strength do saile,</br>Yet feares she not to hold out to the end,</br>She's still the same, and nothing can prevaile,</br>To alter any Good she doth intend.</br>To whom the heav'ns true Constancie do send</br>Within their hearts to dwell, on all occasions</br>Effects most admirable thence transcend,</br>She fils the heart with such secure perswasions;</br>They it defend from all faint-hearted base invasions.

A constant man, the most disastrous fate,</br>With a most pleasing forehead entertaines:</br>Integrity so sweetens his estate,</br>As in a pleasant Calme he ay remaines:</br>With her he alwayes in his heart retaines,</br>Hope, Prudence, Fortitude, Right, Temperance:</br>And when him Troubles, Losses, Griefe or Paines</br>Assaile, so stoutly patience doth advance,</br>He liveth most secure, not subject unto Chance.

Brave noble Constance!  who art never sound,</br>Except dame Prudence thee accompany,</br>Thou on her counsels and advice dost found</br>Thy setled resolutions all, whereby</br>Thou standst most firme for Truth and Honesty;</br>Nothing can thee, thus well resolv'd, withstand.</br>In vaine and evill things no constancie,</br>But base perversnesse, we do understand;</br>Just, honest, profitable's all she takes in hand.

For perseverance in a thing that's ill,</br>Is to this Vertue no lesse enemy,</br>Than they that by affections guide their will,</br>With vaine inconstancy and levitie:</br>Who, of a wanton imbecillity,</br>Stagger and change at ev'ry idle motion;</br>Wind-shaken Reeds, whose instability,</br>Are like the brain-sicke, idle, vaine devotion</br>Of Novellists, drunke with hot humours giddy potion.

Prepost'rous fools!  who when they should frequent</br>Assemblies, hide themselves at home alone;</br>From what they do approve, they soone dissent,</br>Hating what erst they lov'd, dispraise as soone,</br>What erst they liked well:  Lo, such a one,</br>Appeares like Cato's Ape, wondrous severe,</br>With rugged brow; but you may find him soone</br>Dissolv'd in Laughter, or ev'n dead with feare:</br>Such, any publike Office is unfit to beare.

No truth of Judgement or Sinceritie,</br>In such a vaine inconstant mind is found:</br>But Slouth, Fraud, Wantonnesse, Iniquity,</br>With all the basest Vices there abound:</br>This Levity in youth doth age confound</br>With doting madnesse; and a man declares</br>Wise onely then in shew, not inward sound:</br>But then a brave and constant mind appeares,</br>When constant Resolution honours silver haires.

Well said th' old Cynicke, when him friends advise</br>To leave his study, and to take his rest:</br>I am, saith he, now running for a prize,</br>And therefore in the end must run my best.</br>The shorter time of Life to us doth rest,</br>More constantly we to our ayme must rend.</br>Who runs, saith Paul, the race, is never blest</br>With due reward, that holds not to the end:</br>For Constance is the Grace doth all the rest commend.

And as the man, that hard things undertakes,</br>Must alwaies have respect unto the end,</br>Which all precedent bitternesse sweet makes,</br>Be it for pleasure, glory, gaine, or friend;</br>So he that for Gods glory doth contend,</br>And makes it ay his constant end and ayme,</br>As that's immortall, so it him doth send</br>True immortality in heav'n to gaine,</br>Which comforts him for all his Labour, losse, and paine.

As Mountains huge stand fast on their foundation,</br>So constant minds on resolutions sound,</br>As they unmov'd, so without alteration</br>Are good Conclusions built on Vertues ground:</br>A constant man stands on a rocke profound,</br>Which neither stormes, wind, waves, nor force can move:</br>Crosses, afflictions, can no more confound</br>Him, than wind, waves, and stormes, the rocke remove,</br>Whose strong foundation stands on faith, hope, truth and love.

Anselmus doth a constant man compare</br>Unto a sixe-square dye, or hewed stone,</br>The sixe flat-sides, his sixe Conditions are,</br>Freedome, Prosperity, Subjection,</br>Adversity, Life-publique, and alone:</br>On which soever side he chance to fall,</br>He stands upright with resolution,</br>No changes can his constant mind appall,</br>But as he standeth firme on one side, so on all.

As bodily eyes all need Light of Sunne,</br>Whereby they may attaine unto their end,</br>So on all good and vertuous workes begun,</br>This holy Vertue Constance must attend:</br>And as except the Sunne his Light doth lend,</br>We open in the darke our eyes in vaine,</br>So vainely we good holy workes intend,</br>Except we constant to the end remaine,</br>Like Pilot drown'd in hav'n, when he hath scapt the Maine.

Is't not absur'd, that we should early rise,</br>Lose sleepe, broile with Suns heat, and take great paine,</br>Onely to winne a fading worthlesse prize,</br>And give in, when we sure be to obtaine</br>A Crowne, which shall for ever make us raigne?</br>Except the Souldier Constant be and bold,</br>His Captaines favour he shall never gaine,</br>Unlesse our spirituall fight we constant hold,</br>Gods comfortable face we never shall behold.

She is the Nurse of Merit, friend of Peace,</br>Way to Reward, sister of Patience,</br>True friendships Band, pure Sanctities increase:</br>Take away Constance, Bounties excellence</br>Doth fade, and Duty wants her recompence;</br>High Fortitude doth want her commendation.</br>She is alone the noble Grace, from whence</br>All other Graces have their Consummation:</br>To her is giv'n, or rather she gives man salvation.

What more like unto God than Constancie?</br>Who ay like Sunne in heav'n remaines the same,</br>Though to descend to mans capacity,</br>He often seeme to change his mind and name.</br>The Scriptures then mans changing closely blame,</br>When they affirme, God grieves, or doth repent:</br>'Tis flesh that alters, God is still the same:</br>So clouds seeme oft to change the Firmament,</br>Which till the Day of Doome stands firme and permanent.

When as she hath a constat of the right,</br>She therein perseveres unto the end:</br>Therefore of constat she is Constance hight;</br>And well this name her nature doth commend.</br>Her understanding first doth apprehend</br>Things to be good, before she doth beginne:</br>Then she most constantly doth ay intend,</br>When she consid'rately hath entred in:</br>Thus all the Saints on earth, a roome in heav'n must win.

And though all flesh, by our first Parents fall,</br>Are so unconstant, vaine, and wavering,</br>They have in words, thoughts, actions, and all,</br>Of Eves fond ficklenesse a relishing:</br>Lo Enoch yet constant persevering</br>To walke with God, till he him takes away:</br>And Noah, constant in the publishing</br>Of true Repentance, ev'n untill the day,</br>Flouds come and drowne all Flesh without the Arke that stay.

Abram most constant in beleefe we find:</br>No feare nor terror Jacob could dismay:</br>Joseph had rather yron linkes should bind</br>His lims, than from chast Constancie to stray.</br>So long as hard'ned Memphians disobay,</br>Moses most constantly for plagues doth call:</br>Lo Josuahs courage lengthens out the day,</br>Till he Gods enemies destroyeth all;</br>No force, nor fury can his constant mind appall.

I number may the Starres of heav'n as well,</br>As here the Mirrors all of Constance count,</br>Who champions brave against world, flesh, and hell,</br>In Fortitude and Patience surmount:</br>Many of them I formerly recount,</br>In Fortitudes and Patience Meditation,</br>They all arise from one faire heav'nly fount,</br>That clensing Laver of Regeneration,</br>Though glittring shows we find oft with the heathen nation.

Ile name one Carthage prisoner for all,</br>Who, upon promise to returne againe,</br>Was sent to Rome, the Senate there to call,</br>Them to perswade against their Cities gaine:</br>But he most nobly will not yeeld to staine</br>His Countries glory, for his private good,</br>But constantly perswades them to maintaine</br>Their honour, though he seal'd it with his blood,</br>And constant still the same against all tortures stood.

His noble mind their cruelties derides,</br>His Executioners are wearied,</br>Yet constant he and cheerefull all abides,</br>Griefe, gaine, for Countries good, he reckoned.</br>Yet hath this Constancie beene conquered</br>By thousand Martyrs, which most willingly</br>For Syons glory have beene martyred;</br>Who when their flesh doth broile, and bowels frie,</br>Sing joyfull Hallelujahs to God on hie.

Yet are these, but as Candles to the Sunne,</br>Compared with the constant Lord of all:</br>Beginne we with his apprehension,</br>When his Disciples all from him do fall,</br>Behold him in the high Priests Judgment-hall.</br>See Herods men of warre him foule deride:</br>Condemn'd by Pilate, scorn'd, abus'd of all:</br>The theefe that raileth, hanging by his side,</br>Yet he most valiant, constant, patient, doth abide.

But now the Sunne ascended is above,</br>Th' Apostles will their Light no longer hide,</br>They constantly before the Rulers prove,</br>That they the Lord of Life had crucifide:</br>And when they are before those Rulers tride,</br>And charg'd to preach no more in Jesus name,</br>They most couragious, constantly replide,</br>Be judges, whether it were greater blame,</br>You now to disobay or God who us did frame.

Paul ready is not onely to be bound,</br>But at Hierusalem for Christ to die,</br>He patient is in all afflictions found,</br>Constant in losses, joy, prosperity:</br>Read his imprisonments brave history,</br>You there shall more divine Idea's find,</br>Than Homer, Virgil, Spencer, can supply,</br>Though they in loftiest straines the form have lin'd</br>Of a most brave, heroicke, constant, noble mind.

These, as they saw their patterne set before,</br>Unto the Races end most constant run,</br>But yet their Fortitude's increased more,</br>By Confidence, that he which hath begun</br>So good a worke, it will not leave undone:</br>Let Divels try by crosses and tentation,</br>Hold constant to the end, the Crowne is won.</br>Though for a while we suffer tribulation,</br>A noble, constant mind stands without perturbation.

I do confesse 'tis difficult and rare,</br>To know ones-selfe; but to be still the same,</br>Is chiefest worke, of all the workes that are:</br>He that so constantly his mind can frame,</br>Deserves the honour of a constant name:</br>He's neere to glorious vertues consummation;</br>His soule minds only heav'n, from whence it came,</br>Secure and free from worlds vaine molestation,</br>And waites heav'ns leisure only for his glad translation.

Not that I constant Idlenesse commend,</br>Or a retired Life monasticall;</br>No, Constance alwayes Labour doth intend,</br>And is the same approv'd and seene of all:</br>Her words, lookes, gesture, are heroicall;</br>She makes the Body strong, confirmes the mind.</br>Ah!  wo to them, that from her fauour fall,</br>And leave the right, the crooked way to find;</br>These grieve the Angels, which to guard them are assign'd.

Grant in Prosperity a prudent heart,</br>And in Adversity a mind upright;</br>So shall no pleasures vaine my Soule pervert,</br>Nor crosses or tentations me affright:</br>My selfe I with Gods blessings will delight,</br>So long as please his Bounty them to lend.</br>If I must suffer here for doing right,</br>I to the Just one will my cause commend,</br>Where I am sure to have a just and equall end.

The end, whereon all that is past depends,</br>If then we have a constant resolution,</br>A holy Life shall bring us happy ends,</br>Then comes our Fate, to justest reuolution:</br>We then of Adams losse have restitution,</br>Ah!  all our Labour hath but beene in vaine,</br>If Courage faint in point of Dissolution:</br>This is the howre we happinesse attaine,</br>Or else for ever in hels torments must remaine.

Lord make me ever mindfull of this Hower,</br>That constant alwayes I may stand prepar'd,</br>Grant me with boldnesse to declare thy power,</br>And in the right of none to be afeard:</br>True happinesse is Constancies reward,</br>A high reward, but he it sure shall gaine,</br>That to the end holds out with due regard.</br>Things hardest, Perseverance will attaine,</br>And Constancy will make them ay with us remaine.

Then stand we firme, in what we have begun,</br>And labour constantly more to obtaine,</br>Lo, thus we heav'n upon the earth have won:</br>Thus we that true Security attaine,</br>Which ev'ry wise and good man seeks to gaine:</br>No Greatnesse, King, or Kesar is so high,</br>As those that over their affections raigne:</br>Here Peace of Conscience brings Security,</br>Saints wished true content, and Angels Dignity.

Most blessed Port, that Pilgrims can attaine!</br>Till they arrive at hav'n of Happinesse,</br>Pure Joy of heart, which onely they do gaine,</br>Where heav'ns sweet Comforter doth dwel in peace:</br>God of all Comfort, in my heart increase</br>This Constancie, that she may me defend</br>In private, publicke, losse, gaine, paine, and ease,</br>And grant, as I the Graces do commend,</br>I may in all continue constant to the end.</br>
